rdgGrp.n: ['rest', '<del>and bless god if nothing</del>', '', '<del>else</del>', '', '', '', '<del> worse </del>', '<del>happens </del>', '<del>.</del>', '<del> and the idleness generated by grief would </del>', '<del> become a bad habit if further indulged </del>']

['', '<del>see</del>', '', '<del> of </del>', '', '<del>what use learning</del>', '', '<del>was</del>', '', '', '', '<del> could be </del>', '', '<del>to a</del>', '', '<del>merchant.</del>', '', 'henry', 'had']

['<del>had a refined mind; he had no desire to be idle, and was well pleased to become his fatherâ€™s partner, but he believed that a man might be a very good trader, and yet possess a cultivated understanding.</del>', 'loved poetry and his mind was filled with the imagery and sublime sentiments of the masters of that art. a poet himself, he turned with <del>y</del-inner> disgust from the details of ordinary life. his own <del>soul</del-inner> mind was all the possession that he prized, beautiful and majestic thoughts the only wealth he covetedâ€”daring as the eagle and as free, common laws could not be applied to him; and while you gazed on him you felt his soulâ€™s spark was more divineâ€”more truly stolen from apolloâ€™s sacred fire, than the glimmering ember that animates other men.']
['<del>to his statement, which was delivered</del>', 'to him with interest for he spoke']

['<note>if there were ever to be another edition of this book, i should re-write these two first chapters. the incidents are tame and ill-arrangedâ€”the language sometimes childish.â€”they are unworthy of the rest of the <del>w book</del>narration.</note>']
